newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: KABILA TO MEET MANDELA FOR ZAIRE TALKS IN CAPE TOWN.
newsitem.headline: KABILA TO MEET MANDELA FOR ZAIRE TALKS IN CAPE TOWN.

text.p: Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila will meet South African President Nelson Mandela in Cape Town on Wednesday evening for talks on the troubled central African state, government sources said.
Kabila would meet Mandela at his Cape Town residence, Genadendal, to explore ways to bring peace to Zaire, one senior source said.
Mandela was trying to arrange a direct meeting in South Africa between Kabila and ailing Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko.
No definite arrangement had been made for a face-to-face meeting between the two rivals, but he predicted it could take place by the weekend.
Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Aziz Pahad, who was instrumental in arranging an earlier round of talks in South Africa between the Zairean rivals, was expected to attend Wednesday night's talks.
Witnesses said Kabila left Zaire's Lubumbashi airport for South Africa earlier in the day, but there was no word on the movements of the Zairean president.
Sources said the U.N. special representative on Zaire, Mohamed Sahnoun, had arrived with a delegation in Cape Town on Wednesday morning.
The sources declined any further comment on talks, saying it would be for the rebels and the Zairean government to make any statements.

Kabila departed at 11.40 a.m. (0940 GMT) on a South African Air Force jet bound for Cape Town after a two-day visit to Zaire's second largest city to mark his rebels' capture of the mineral-rich Shaba province.
Speaking to reporters at the airport, he again asserted that nothing would halt his drive to unseat Mobutu.
"There will no ceasefire until Mobutu relinquishes power," the rebel leader said.
South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo on Tuesday predicted dramatic progress within days in ending the civil war in Zaire.
The rebels now control more than half of Africa's third largest country, and Kabila says he is targeting the capital Kinshasa in a bid to drive the ailing Mobutu from power.
